ygData.subject: Filters vs. DecideRules Re: [archive-crawler] Re: Release 1.10.0 pending

Hi Gordon,

it does make perfect sense to me, so I refactored my
DocumentLe=
ngthFilter into a pair of DecideRules:

NotExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDec=
ideRule.java
and
ExceedsDocumentLengthTresholdDecideRule.java

Hope you lik=
e it this way. If this looks fine, I'll rework my other
filter, too. (And m=
aybe rework a few other filters into deciderules, too.)

Olaf Freyer


--- =
In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
>
> Ola=
f -
> 
> THanks for the contributions!
> 
> What would you think about reca=
sting the Filters as DecideRules?
> 
> Filters have historically been prone=
 to confusion: are they "filtering
> in" or "filtering out", or more concre=
tely, what does 'true' mean?
> 
> It's varied in different settings -- some=
times 'true' means 'exclude'
> and others 'include' -- and thus some filter=
s have an 'if-match-return'
> capability to make them usable in a reverse s=
ense. But that can just
> add to the number of things you need to keep trac=
k of; even experienced 
> crawl operators at IA often get these backwards.
=
> 
> DecideRules add a little more complexity but are more explicit in thei=
r
> intended effects:
>   - they answer ACCEPT, REJECT, or PASS
>   - by ch=
aining them, with some PASSes, they can achieve most of the
same
>     resu=
lts that would require deep nesting of binary filters (with
>     logical c=
ombiners like AND/OR)
>   - in chains, the last non-PASS decision 'wins'
> =
  - by convention, pairs of DecideRule implementations are used, instead
> =
    of a setting that inverts their conditional
> 
> An illustrative exampl=
e is the difference between URIRegExpFilter, and
> the pair of DecideRules =
MatchesRegExpDecideRule and
> NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule.
> 
> With URIRegE=
xpFilter, you can answer only true or false. You need to
> consider what an=
swer the context requires, and via the 'if-match-return'
> setting, you can=
 control whether a regex match means 'true' or 'false'.
> 
> But it's quite=
 likely that the regex is not the final word -- if it
> matches, the URI is=
 'out', but if it fails to match, the URI may not
> necessarily be 'in' or =
'out' -- other rules then kick in. So the 
> non-match answer has to be log=
ically combined with other filter results.
> 
> With the MatchesRegExpDecid=
eRule or NotMatchesRegExpDecideRule, you can
> arrange for any of the follo=
wing four possibilities:
> 
> ACCEPT if matches, PASS otherwise
> REJECT if=
 matches, PASS otherwise
> ACCEPT if not matches, PASS otherwise
> REJECT i=
f not matches, PASS otherwise
> 
> The named return values constrain the us=
age context to interpret the
> answer in a certain way -- no "does true mea=
n 'include' or 'exclude'
> here?" confusion -- and the PASS lets one rule o=
f a group contribute
> nothing to the final decision, if its condition isn'=
t met. (No need to 
> wrap it in a AND/OR to express operator intent.)
> 
>=
 (By prepending such a rule with an all-ACCEPT or all-REJECT rule, you
> ca=
n set a 'default' answer for PASS.)
> 
> So that DecideRules can be used an=
ywhere Filters were, there is a 
> DecidingFilter class, which lets (chains=
 of) DecideRules be used to 
> render a Filter true/false response. But we =
generally prefer to use 
> DecideRules in new contexts, and if there's a ne=
w CrawlURI-test to be 
> implemented, would like it implemented as a Decide=
Rule rather than a 
> Filter. Then it can be used in Filter contexts (via D=
ecidingFilter) and 
> DecideRule contexts.
> 
> Does that make sense?
> 
> =
- Gordon @ IA
> 
> pandae667 wrote:
> > Hi Michael,
> > 
> > I just added 3=
 tiny contributions to the "Feature Request" tracker I'd
> > like to see in=
 the forthcoming release. Those are:
> > 
> > - [1545840] ContentLengthFilt=
er (multi-purpose content-length based
> > filter. either  determines lengt=
h via HTTP header when used as
> > midfetch filter or otherwise based on ac=
tual downloaded document size)
> > 
> > - [1545842] SuccessfulFetchFilter (=
simple stupid HTTP 2xx filter)
> > 
> > - [1545847] a way to simply tell he=
ritrix to look for its configs in a
> > different location.
> > 
> > Would =
be happy to see some or all of them in the forthcoming release
> > (would m=
ake updating alot easier for me ;-) )
> > 
> > Any comments are welcome
> >=
   Olaf Freyer
